awd_titl_txt: EFRI NewLAW: Topological acoustic metamaterials for programmable and high-efficiency one-way transport
awd_abstract_narration:
In this research, physicists, wave mechanicians and materials scientists will come together to design, fabricate and characterize novel metamaterials with nonreciprocal wave propagation attributes.  The field of sound waves, which represent the oldest way of communication between human beings, is experiencing a revival in the context of modern material technology and engineering, with a myriad of applications ranging from medical imaging and echolocation to acoustic cloaking.  A fundamental principle governing wave propagation in both fluid and solid media, called "reciprocity", is that the transmission rate of waves must be equal forward and backward between any two arbitrarily selected points in a medium.  The ability to break this principle, that is, the realization of one-directional mechanical or acoustic "diodes" will enable the design of new classes of mechanical systems with novel functionalities, including adaptive sensors and vibration isolation devices. It will also provide a transformative contribution to the emerging field of material logic, a design paradigm where simple structural and material modules are used as the engineering building blocks to create mechanical devices of arbitrary complexity.  The core conceptual ideas behind the research originate from the notion of "topological protection", which is exploited to obtain wave propagation properties that are robust against disorder and noise. The knowledge developed through this research will advance technologies, including but not limited to: a) mechanical computing, where acoustic logic ports can be seen as building blocks capable of carrying out an array of mathematical operations, and b) devices with novel thermal transport properties, exploiting the analogy between thermal phonons and mechanical vibrations at the spatial and temporal scales of mechanical devices. The research will also be disseminated to the broader community through a workshop with public tutorials, broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in STEM fields through enhancing existing programs at the different academic institutions and will result in YouTube videos to share the discoveries with the general public.

This project will develop a fundamental understanding of how the phonon band topology governs the acoustic properties of systems experiencing spatial-temporal modulation, leading to a formal interpretation framework for this type of time-reversal symmetry breaking phenomena. The powerful toolkits to be developed through the project will allow for a rich variety of designs beyond the current boundaries of the use of topological states in acoustic wave control strategies. The research will span frontiers of condensed matter physics, wave mechanics, and materials science.  The two main conceptual ideas to be used for the realization of topologically protected nonreciprocal wave propagation are: (1) program the phonon band structure in spatial-temporal modulated materials using principles of topological band theory, and (2) exploit the contrasting wave propagation properties of Maxwell lattices in their metal-like and topological insulator-like phases.  The research team will advance the theoretical understanding of the intimate role played by topological protection in nonreciprocal wave propagation, use state-of-the-art fabrication techniques to realize prototypes of acoustic diodes at different scales using a variety of material platforms, and deploy laser-enabled wave reconstruction capabilities to characterize the nonreciprocal wave propagation phenomena in the fabricated metamaterial specimen. By developing and applying principles of topology and material logic design across the scales, the project will transform a set of simple mechanical components into a versatile platform for the next generation acoustic logic ports with programmable acoustic transport and time reversal symmetry breaking capabilities.

por.por_cntn:
The objective of this EFRI project is to conceptualize and realize materials exhibiting novel wave propagation characteristics structure design, known as acoustic metamaterials.  The main design principle employed in this project is topological mechanical states, whereby controlling the topology of the vibrational wave functions, we aim to confer unconventional, robust, and switchable acoustic features to these materials.  This includes one-way transport where acoustic waves propagate in one direction while suppressing the propagation in the opposite direction.

In this project we gained fundamental new understandings of topological acoustic metamaterials by designing and testing a suite of metamaterials with topological waves.  Our scientific achievements can be summarized to two main areas.  (i) We developed and experimentally tested new theories for topological edge wave propagation in Maxwell lattice topological metamaterials, extending the frontiers of our knowledge in multiple fronts including asymmetric topological wave propagation, omni-modal topological polarization coupling in-plane and out-of-plane excitations (Fig 1), nonlinear one-way topological transport, and aperiodic topological metamaterials with quasi-crystalline order.  (ii) We explored the combination of material features, length scales, and topological acoustics.  Using shape memory polymers and photolithography, we achieved a monolithic Maxwell lattice with sub-millimeter features, which can be transformed between states of different topological indices and sharply different mechanical properties (Fig 2).  In addition, we have formulated a number of novel theories of topological mechanics including fractional topological excitations in mechanical systems and topological mechanical states in biological tissues.  Our results have been disseminated to the metamaterials community and beyond via 35 peer reviewed scientific journal publications and many invited presentations at international conferences.

This project has provided training opportunities to a diverse team of young scientists including graduate and undergraduate students and postdocs, who gained knowledge in this exciting interdisciplinary field of metamaterials.  We have also strived to deploy a comprehensive and vigorous outreach plan.  The UM team developed a series of science demos centered around mechanical metamaterials and delivered them at outreach events hosted by the University of Michigan Museum of Natural History, developed a new undergraduate course on “Physics of Art” highlighting the interplay of art and metamaterials for students from humanities and social science, and delivered a public lecture on “From Nobel prize research to the breakthrough technologies transforming our lives” at the popular venue of Saturday Morning Physics hosted by the Department of Physics at UM.  The UMN team has developed – working with undergraduate students - a gallery of 3D-printed metamaterials prototypes, including negative-Poisson-ratio lattices and Maxwell lattices, to be used for hands-on demonstrations of metamaterials functionalities in outreach events. Outreach efforts have included participation in the Civil Engineering Day at the Science Museum of Minnesota and collaborations with local high schools, with plans for more events featuring the prototype gallery in the near future.  The Penn team has participated in Philly Materials Day every year, which attracts over one thousand k-12 students in Philadelphia regions, presenting the general concept of responsive materials using hydrogels as examples, and illustrating geometric effect to materials mechanical properties using folded papers.

In summary, this EFRI project pushed the boundary of the science and engineering of topological acoustic metamaterials, exploring not only new types of waves but also novel combinations of material properties with topological states.  Additionally, the project played a vital role in training a team of young scientists and in disseminating the excitement of science and engineering to the public.
